{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14963,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asclepias variegata, or white milkweed, thrives best with moderate watering. It's important to ensure that the soil is well-drained to avoid waterlogging, as it prefers not to be in excessively moist conditions. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch, typically once a week, adjusting frequency depending on temperature and humidity. In cooler months, reduce watering as growth slows. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so always allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Mulching can help retain moisture and keep roots cool during the growing season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"White milkweed prefers partial to full sunlight. It thrives best in areas where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from scorching. If growing indoors or in a shaded area, ensure it receives bright indirect light to mimic its natural habitat. Lack of sufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so aim to place it in a position where it will be basked in plenty of light for optimal health and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias variegata is mainly about maintaining plant health and encouraging a neat shape. In late winter or early spring, before new growth starts, remove any dead stems or foliage to allow sunlight and air to reach the plant's base. Regularly deadhead the flowers after they fade to encourage further blooming and to prevent seed formation unless you wish for the plant to self-seed. Pruning helps manage the plant’s size and shape, ensuring vigorous growth and healthy foliage. Take care not to remove too much live growth, as it can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"redring milkweed","description":"Asclepias variegata, commonly called the redring milkweed or white milkweed, is a plant in the dogbane family. It is native to eastern North America, where it is found in Canada and the United States. It is most common in the Southeastern United States, and becomes rare in the northern edge of its range.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["redring milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias variegata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15059,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sacoila lanceolata, commonly known as the leafless beaked orchid, requires moderate watering to thrive. This plant generally prefers well-drained soil and should not be kept overly wet, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry, allowing the potting medium to dry out slightly between waterings. During its active growing season, increase the frequency of watering but reduce it in the dormant phase. It's crucial to ensure that the plant has adequate drainage to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sacoila lanceolata thrives in environments with ample indirect sunlight. It should be placed in a location that receives bright, filtered light for the majority of the day. Direct sunlight may scorch the plant’s delicate structures, so a spot with partial shade or diffused lighting is ideal. An east or west-facing window with sheer curtains can provide the right conditions. If grown indoors, artificial grow lights that mimic natural sunlight can supplement during shorter winter days to ensure the plant receives the adequate light for photosynthesis and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sacoila lanceolata is primarily focused on maintaining its aesthetic appeal and health. Since this orchid doesn't have many leaves, pruning is minimal and mostly involves removing dead or yellowing stems. This should be done using sharp, sterilized scissors to prevent disease. Cut back any unhealthy parts during the dormancy period, which helps encourage new growth during the growing season. Care should also be taken to avoid disturbing the healthy roots and ensure that the pruning is done gently and sparingly to avoid stressing the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Leafless Beaked Lady Orchid","description":"Sacoila lanceolata, commonly referred to as leafless beaked orchid, is a species of flowering plant that grows in Florida the West Indies, Mexico, Central America, and South America. It grows in swamps and hydric hammocks including along roadsides. A varietal grows in South Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Florida","Central America","South America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["Leafless Beaked Lady Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Sacoila lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14169,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Chondracanthus canaliculatus, commonly known as the Channelled Wrack, thrives best in natural tidal conditions, which naturally provide moisture through tidal flow or spray. When cultivating in a controlled environment, simulate these conditions by ensuring the plant has constant access to water or is kept in high-humidity conditions. Regularly mist the plants if necessary, ensuring they do not dry out. The key is maintaining consistent wetness without allowing the plant to be submerged without natural tidal movement."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chondracanthus canaliculatus thrives in intertidal zones, indicating that it can handle varying levels of sunlight. For optimal growth in controlled settings, replicate its natural environment by providing indirect sunlight or light that's diffused through water. In outdoor settings or in aquatics exhibits, place in areas where it receives partial sunlight; too much direct sunlight can lead to desiccation and damage, while too little can hinder its growth. Aim for a balanced light exposure, similar to what it would experience natively among rocks and tide pools."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Chondracanthus canaliculatus involves minimal intervention as it is primarily a seaweed species found in tidal zones. In environments where it’s cultivated for research or decorative purposes, remove any dead or decaying portions to prevent the spread of decay and to promote better growth. Regular cleaning is vital, as detritus or other substances can adhere to the plant, affecting its health. Focus on maintaining its shape naturally, avoiding excessive trimming which can lead to stress for its natural regrowth processes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lawn alga","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan"],"other_name":["Lawn alga"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Chondracanthus canaliculatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15757,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arnoglossum atriplicifolium, commonly known as pale Indian plantain, prefers consistent moisture. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains evenly moist, but not waterlogged. During dry spells, especially in the plant’s active growing season, increase watering to prevent the soil from drying out completely. It's vital to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant sits in soggy soil for too long. Using mulch can also help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arnoglossum atriplicifolium thrives in full sun to part shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In hot summer regions, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching and ensure the plant maintains its lush appearance. However, ensure that the plant isn't shaded too much, as inadequate sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and leggy growth. If grown indoors, position near a bright east or west-facing window to simulate these conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Arnoglossum atriplicifolium, regular pruning can help maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune during the dormant season, typically in late fall or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems and foliage to prevent the spread of disease and promote robust growth. Deadheading spent flowers can also prolong blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, it can be cut back more severely to control its size and improve air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pale Indian plantain","description":"Arnoglossum atriplicifolium (pale Indian plantain) is a perennial North American wildflower in the sunflower family. It is widely distributed through the central and eastern states of the United States from the Atlantic Coast westward as far as Kansas, but it is listed as endangered in the state of New Jersey.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["pale Indian plantain"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leafhoppers","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Arnoglossum atriplicifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy Loam","Clay Loam"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14462,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiranthes cernua, commonly known as Nodding Lady's Tresses, prefers consistently moist soil conditions but should not be waterlogged. Ensure that the plant's substrate drains well to prevent root rot. In its growing season, usually from spring through summer, water the plant regularly to maintain the moisture necessary for growth. In fall, as the plant starts to go dormant, reduce watering but ensure that the plant still receives enough to keep the soil slightly moist. Using rainwater or distilled water is preferred over tap water to avoid salt accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiranthes cernua thrives in conditions of dappled sunlight or partial shade, mimicking their natural woodland habitat. They prefer morning sun with some protection from the intense afternoon rays, which can scorch plants if too strong. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east-facing window where it gets gentle morning light can mimic these conditions. During the growing season, ensuring they receive enough light will promote healthy growth and flowering, but be cautious of excessively harsh direct sunlight during peak heating hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Spiranthes cernua is relatively minimal. Remove any dead or dying floral stalks after the flower has faded to encourage further growth and prevent any potential diseases. As the plant goes dormant in winter, leaves may naturally die back; these can be gently removed to tidy up the plant. Be careful not to damage emerging shoots during pruning. Other than removing dead or spent growth, these orchids do not require extensive pruning to thrive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"nodding ladies' tresses","description":"Spiranthes cernua, commonly called the nodding lady's tresses, is a species of orchid occurring from Eastern Canada to the central and eastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["nodding ladies' tresses"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spiranthes cernua"],"soil":["Moist","Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15658,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vitis mustangensis, also known as Mustang Grape, prefers well-drained soil and requires regular watering to establish its roots, especially in the first year. Typically, watering deeply once a week during dry spells is adequate. Ensure the plant receives sufficient moisture during its active growing season in spring and summer, while reducing water supply during dormancy in winter. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot; allow the topsoil to dry out between waterings. It's important to adjust watering based on rainfall and soil moisture conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitis mustangensis thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce healthy foliage and fruit. Planting the vine in a sunny location encourages vigorous growth and better fruiting. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced vigor and fewer grape clusters. In regions with extremely hot conditions, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Ensuring adequate sunlight exposure is essential for the plant to develop strong vines and stay resilient against common diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitis mustangensis is crucial for maintaining health, managing growth, and improving fruit production. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring when the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing vines to promote air circulation. Additionally, trim back the previous year’s growth, leaving a few healthy buds on each cane to encourage new shoots. This selective pruning helps in forming a sturdy structure for the vine, which can also prevent overcrowding and disease. Regular maintenance checks throughout the growing season ensure continued vigor and control of unruly growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mustang grape","description":"Vitis mustangensis, commonly known as the mustang grape, is a species of grape that is native to the southern United States. Its range includes parts of Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas, and Oklahoma.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["mustang grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Bacterial Blight","Black Rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vitis mustangensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15362,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Banksia ericifolia, commonly known as Heath-leaved Banksia, is drought-tolerant and requires moderate watering, especially once established. Initially, water regularly to help young plants establish roots, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged. As the plant matures, reduce watering frequency, providing water during prolonged dry spells. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot. In very well-draining soil, you may need to water a bit more frequently during dry periods. Always consider local climate conditions to adjust watering needs accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Banksia ericifolia thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. This plant can tolerate partial shade but may not produce as many flowers in lower light conditions. Providing ample sunlight ensures robust growth and vibrant blooms. In excessively hot climates, some light afternoon shade can help protect it from the harsh afternoon sun. Choose a planting spot that receives ample morning light to maximize its growth potential. Ensure the location has good air circulation to prevent fungal issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Banksia ericifolia should be done to maintain shape and encourage bushy growth. Perform light pruning after flowering, cutting back spent flower spikes and any straggly or unruly branches to promote denser foliage. Avoid cutting into old wood as this can prevent new growth. Remove any dead or diseased branches to ensure plant health. Pruning should ideally be done in late spring or early summer, right after flowering has finished. Regular pruning helps maintain a compact form and improves the overall aesthetic and health of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Heath-leaved banksia","description":"Banksia ericifolia, the heath-leaved banksia (also known as the lantern banksia or heath banksia), is a species of woody shrub of the family Proteaceae native to Australia. It grows in two separate regions of Central and Northern New South Wales east of the Great Dividing Range. Well known for its orange or red autumn inflorescences, which contrast with its green fine-leaved heath-like foliage, it is a medium to large shrub that can reach 6 m (20 ft) high...","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Heath-leaved banksia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Banksia ericifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always reduce watering in fall and winter, allowing the soil to dry out a bit more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera fruticosa thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce its vibrant yellow flowers. The plant can tolerate partial shade, but it may result in less vigorous blooming and a leggier growth habit. Ensure the plant receives ample morning sunlight, especially in hotter climates where the afternoon sun can be overly intense. Positioning it in a south-facing area of the garden is ideal for optimal growth and flowering. Adequate sunlight is crucial for maintaining its health and ensuring a profusion of blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera fruticosa involves removing spent blooms to encourage prolonged flowering and prevent unwanted seeding. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14365,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae, commonly known as the Green-fly Orchid, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It's important to ensure the growing medium is slightly moist but not soggy, as overwatering can lead to root rot. During the growing season, which is typically in the spring and summer, water the plant more frequently, allowing the media to dry out slightly between waterings. In the fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows. It's crucial to use water that is free from salts and chemicals, such as rainwater or distilled water, to prevent damage to the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae thrives in bright but indirect sunlight. It generally prefers light conditions similar to its natural habitat where it grows under tree canopies. Therefore, placing the plant in an area where it can receive dappled sunlight for several hours a day is ideal. Direct sunlight should be avoided, especially the harsh afternoon sun, as it can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, a location near an east or west-facing window works well. If the plant's leaves are dark green, it may require more light, and if they are yellowing, it may need less. Adjust accordingly to maintain healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Epidendrum magnoliae is generally minimal. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves with clean, sharp scissors to maintain plant health and appearance. It's also beneficial to cut off spent flower spikes once the flowers have faded to encourage new growth and prevent nutrient drain on the plant. Be careful not to remove green, healthy leaves as they contribute to photosynthesis. Pruning should be done whenever there's noticeable dead growth, and always use sterile tools to prevent disease spread. Pruning will help keep the plant tidy and focused on producing healthy, new shoots and blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Greenfly Orchid","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae, sometimes called Epidendrum conopseum or the green-fly orchid, is a species of orchid in the genus Epidendrum. It is the most northern-growing epiphytic orchid in North America, being found wild in the southeastern United States from Louisiana to North Carolina, and also in northeastern Mexico (Nuevo León, San Luis Potosí, Tamaulipas).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Cuba"],"other_name":["Greenfly Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Epidendrum magnoliae"],"soil":["Well-drained","Organic-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

LED or fluorescent lights specifically designed for marine tanks should be used, with appropriate intensity to mimic natural light conditions. Ensure the light remains on for around 8-12 hours a day, creating a day-night cycle to support its natural growth and biological rhythms. Avoid exposing it to direct, intense light that could lead to overheating or bleaching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mastocarpus papillatus isn't a common practice since it is an algae that grows in marine environments. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14666,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zeuxine strateumatica, commonly known as the lawn orchid, prefers to be kept evenly moist, but not waterlogged. In its dormant period, reduce watering to keep the soil just barely moist. It's important to use soft water, low in minerals, to prevent salt buildup which can harm the plant. Always adjust watering frequency based on the environmental conditions and the humidity level in your area."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zeuxine strateumatica thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It prefers dappled light similar to its natural habitat under the canopy of trees. Avoid direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, as this can cause leaf scorch. Morning sun or a well-lit room with filtered light is ideal. If kept indoors, placing it near an east or north-facing window can simulate its preferred natural conditions. Adjust light exposure during seasonal changes to ensure it receives adequate illumination for optimal growth without stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"This orchid species does not require extensive pruning. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to prevent decay and to maintain a healthy appearance. Pruning is mostly about cleanliness and ensuring that any diseased or damaged parts are promptly removed to avoid spreading pathogens. As Zeuxine strateumatica is a terrestrial orchid, you should be cautious when handling it to avoid damaging the root system, which can be sensitive. Keeping your tools clean when pruning will help maintain the health of this delicate plant."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"centipede grass orchid","description":"Zeuxine strateumatica, common names lawn orchid or soldier orchid, is a species of terrestrial orchids. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14764,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hamelia patens, commonly known as the Firebush, requires regular watering, especially during its first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week in dry conditions, allowing the soil to dry out in between waterings to prevent overwatering. Once established, Hamelia patens is moderately drought-tolerant and can survive on less frequent watering. However, during prolonged dry spells or hot weather, additional watering may be necessary to promote blooming and maintain vibrant foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hamelia patens thrives in full sun, meaning it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow and bloom optimally. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. In hot, sunny climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. In northern climates or areas with less intense sunshine, position the plant in the sunniest location possible to ensure vigorous flowering and healthy growth. Ensuring adequate sunlight is crucial for making the most of this plant's colorful appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Firebush benefits from occasional pruning to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Pruning should be done in early spring before new growth starts, removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Additionally, light pruning throughout the growing season can promote continuous blooming. When pruning, trim back the shoots lightly to maintain the desired size and shape. In colder climates where the plant may die back over winter, pruning the dead wood back in spring will encourage vigorous new growth when the temperatures rise."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Firebush","description":"Hamelia patens is a large perennial shrub or small tree in the coffee family, Rubiaceae, that is native to the American subtropics and tropics. Its range extends from Florida in the southern United States to as far south as Argentina. Common names include firebush, hummingbird bush, scarlet bush, and redhead. In Belize, this plant's Mayan name is Ix Canaan and is also known as \"Guardian of the Forest\".","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Florida","South America","Central America"],"other_name":["Firebush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider Mites","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hamelia patens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Take care not to let it dry out completely, particularly in hot weather. Mulching around the base with organic material can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. However, in cool, humid climates, natural rainfall may suffice, and additional watering might not be necessary. Adjust watering frequency based on the season and climate to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calluna vulgaris thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive between 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade would be beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat. Too much shade may lead to reduced flowering and can cause the plant to become leggy. In cooler climates, full sun is preferable to ensure robust growth and vibrant blooms. It's crucial to strike a balance to provide adequate sunlight without overexposing the plant to harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for Calluna vulgaris to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is in the spring after the last frost, or immediately after flowering in late summer to autumn. Trim the plant lightly by removing faded flowers and cutting back any unruly or woody stems. Avoid cutting into old, brown wood as this can harm the plant. Regular pruning helps to prevent legginess and encourages a bushy, vibrant appearance. Consistent pruning will result in more flowers and a healthier plant overall, extending its lifespan and beauty."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common heather","description":"Calluna vulgaris (known as common heather, ling, or simply heather) is the sole species in the genus Calluna in the flowering plant family Ericaceae. It is a low-growing perennial shrub growing to 20 to 50 centimetres (7.9 to 19.7 in) tall, or rarely to 1 metre (39 in) and taller, and is found widely in Europe and Asia Minor on acidic soils in open sunny situations and in moderate shade. It is the dominant plant in most heathland...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia Minor"],"other_name":["common heather"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Calluna vulgaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14965,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Paeonia lactiflora, commonly known as the Chinese peony, requires a moderate watering routine. During the growing season, particularly in spring and early summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Water deeply once a week, providing about 1-2 inches of water, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. During dormant periods in late summer and fall, reduce watering frequency. Too much moisture can lead to fungal diseases, so avoid watering the foliage directly and water early in the day to allow leaves to dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paeonia lactiflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce abundant blooms. In regions with intense summer heat, peonies may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching, although excessive shade will reduce blooming. Ensure that your peony is planted in a location where it receives adequate morning sun and some shelter from the hottest midday rays. This balance of light promotes strong growth and vibrant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Paeonia lactiflora involves removing dead or diseased stems and leaves throughout the growing season to promote healthy growth. After the plant has finished blooming, deadheading the spent flowers encourages energy to go towards root development rather than seed production. In late fall or early winter, after the first frost, cut back the foliage to ground level to protect the plant over winter and reduce disease risk. Clean and disinfect your pruning tools before and after use to prevent spreading any potential pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese peony","description":"Paeonia lactiflora (Chinese peony or common garden peony) is a species of herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the family Paeoniaceae, native to central and eastern Asia from eastern Tibet across northern China to eastern Siberia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Eastern Siberia"],"other_name":["Chinese peony"],"pest_susceptibility":["Gray mold","Powdery mildew","Wilt"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Paeonia lactiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Light maintenance pruning can also be done to control the spread of the plant if it becomes too large for its allotted space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Havard oak","description":"Quercus havardii (common names include shinnery oak, shin oak and Havard oak) is a deciduous, low-growing, thicket-forming shrub that occupies some 2 to 3 million hectares in the southern Great Plains of North America. Once established, watering can be reduced significantly as the plant can tolerate dry soil conditions. In areas with regular rainfall, additional watering may not be necessary unless during prolonged periods of drought."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago bicolor thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In partial shade, the flowering may be less prolific, and the plant may become leggy as it stretches towards the light. Ensuring adequate sunlight not only promotes a sturdy structure but also maximizes the plant’s production of flowers, which can attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies to the garden."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago bicolor involves removing spent flowers, which can encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if that is a concern. In late fall or early spring, prune the plant back to ground level to clean up the foliage and encourage fresh growth for the next season. However, while it enjoys moisture, avoid waterlogged conditions that could lead to root rot. Use well-draining soil to facilitate proper water retention without excessive accumulation. During the active growing season in spring and summer, increase watering frequency, and reduce it in the dormant winter months while ensuring the soil remains slightly moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygala cruciata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to encourage robust blooming and healthy growth. If grown in partial shade, ensure it still gets adequate light, as insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse flowering and leggy growth. In especially hot climates, providing light afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress. Observing the plant's response will help determine the optimal balance of sunlight and shade for your particular environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygala cruciata is not typically necessary for maintaining its health but can help manage its size and shape, especially if it becomes leggy or outgrows its space. Pruning can be done in early spring before new growth begins or immediately after blooming to encourage a Bushier appearance. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems using clean, sharp pruning shears. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can help prolong blooming by redirecting the plant's energy towards new growth and blossoms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cross-leaved milkwort","description":"Polygala cruciata, commonly called drumheads milkwort, is a species of flowering plant in the milkwort family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15858,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mentzelia hispida is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in well-drained soil and requires minimal watering. Generally, water this plant deeply but infrequently, ensuring that the soil has the chance to dry out completely before the next watering. In the growing season, it might require watering every two to three weeks depending on the climate. Reduce watering in winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mentzelia hispida thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. This plant naturally grows in open, sunny environments and is not well-suited for shady areas. Placing it in a south-facing location will ensure it receives the needed light exposure. If grown indoors or in areas with lower sunlight, consider using supplemental grow lights to meet its bright light requirements. Lack of adequate sunlight may result in leggy growth and fewer blooms, so ensure it gets as much direct sunlight as possible for best performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mentzelia hispida is not strictly necessary, but it can be done to maintain its shape and health. Dead or damaged leaves and stems should be removed to encourage new growth and improve air circulation within the plant. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. In terms of shaping, avoid heavy pruning as it could stress the plant. Instead, focus on gently trimming any overgrown or unruly parts. This plant has a naturally sprawling growth habit, so light pruning and regular cleaning up will keep it looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Streambank Stickleaf","description":"Mentzelia hispida is a species of flowering plant in the family Loasaceae known by the common name pega ropa, or \"sticks to clothing\" in Spanish. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14667,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physcia adscendens, a type of lichen, thrives in environments with some humidity but generally does not require direct watering the way traditional plants do. It absorbs water and nutrients from the air, so maintaining an ambient level of moisture is beneficial. In extremely dry conditions or indoors, you can occasionally mist the lichen to simulate its natural habitat, especially during dry seasons. Avoid misting directly with tap water as the chemicals might harm it; rainwater or distilled water is preferable. Remember that overwatering or high moisture can be as harmful as dryness, so balance is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physcia adscendens requires indirect sunlight for optimal growth. It is well-suited to partially shaded positions, where it can receive filtered light. Being an outdoor organism, it typically resides in places that aren't exposed to intense, direct sunlight, as excessive light and heat can desiccate and damage it. If indoors, place it near a north-facing window or use sheer curtains to diffuse the light. Avoid placing it in direct sun for prolonged periods, especially during midday when the sun is strongest, to prevent dehydration and stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for lichens like Physcia adscendens, as they grow slowly and don’t develop in the same way as many vascular plants. However, you may occasionally need to gently clean the surface of the lichen if it becomes covered with dust or debris, which can impede its ability to photosynthesize. Use a soft brush or a gentle stream of water to clean it, ensuring not to damage the delicate structure. If parts of the lichen die off naturally, they can be carefully removed to maintain a clean appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hooded Rosette Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Whitish"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Hooded Rosette Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Physcia adscendens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moderately moist","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14863,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aloe vera requires infrequent watering, as it's a drought-tolerant plant primarily adapted to arid environments. Water the plant deeply but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Typically, watering every two to three weeks is sufficient during growing seasons (spring and summer). In the dormant winter months, water even less frequently. Ensure that the plant is potted in a well-draining soil mix, and use a pot with drainage holes to avoid standing water, which can cause damage to the roots and lower leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloe vera thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of light throughout the day without being subjected to direct sun, which may scorch its leaves. If outdoors, choose a partially shaded location that offers some protection from intense midday sun. If the plant starts to exhibit signs of insufficient light, such as elongated leaves or a lack of compactness, move it to a brighter spot. However, acclimate it gradually to increased light levels to avoid sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aloe vera is simple and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain a healthy appearance and prevent potential diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off the leaves at the base. You can also remove the lower leaves for aesthetic purposes or to harvest the gel. Ensure that any cuts are clean and that no leaf stubs are left, as they can rot. Avoid over-pruning, as alleys require their leaves for storing water; pruning should be minimal and only as needed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"aloe vera","description":"Aloe vera (/ˈæloʊiː/ or /ˈæloʊ/) is a plant species of the genus Aloe. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14262,"attracts":["None"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnopilus sapineus, commonly known as a mushroom rather than a traditional garden plant, doesn't require traditional watering care like houseplants. If cultivating these mushrooms, maintain a moist environment using substrate materials like sawdust or wood chips, ensuring they are slightly moist, but never soggy, to support mycelium growth. Consistent moisture helps sustain the ideal humidity levels needed for healthy fruiting bodies. Monitor the growing medium regularly and add water if it begins to dry out, but be careful to avoid overly damp conditions which can lead to mold or other fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnopilus sapineus typically grows in shaded environments, such as forests where they naturally develop on decaying wood. Therefore, they thrive best in low-light conditions that replicate their natural habitat. If cultivating Gymnopilus sapineus indoors or outdoors, provide indirect sunlight or shaded conditions to mimic this environment. Exposure to direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and negatively impact their growth. Maintain ambient temperatures and humidity that are conducive to fungal growth to ensure a healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a type of fungus, Gymnopilus sapineus does not require pruning. Once mature, water the plant only during extended dry periods, typically once every few weeks. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil drains well and dries out between watering sessions to mimic its natural habitat. Adjust watering frequency based on rainfall and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Artemisia tripartita requires full sun to thrive, which means it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. The plant thrives best in open, sunny areas typical of its native habitats in North America. Adequate sunlight ensures robust growth and enhances its ability to resist pests and diseases. If planted in a garden, place it in a spot that is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures. While it tolerates partial sun, insufficient light may lead to a less dense growth habit and diminished overall health, so prioritize bright locations for planting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Artemisia tripartita involves removing dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health and appearance. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the plant to a manageable size, usually by one-third to one-half of its height. This encourages bushy growth and helps maintain a desirable shape. Regular pruning prevents the plant from becoming leggy or scraggly. Use sharp, clean tools to make precise cuts and avoid spreading disease. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can stress the plant and reduce its vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Threetip Sagebrush","description":"Artemisia tripartita is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common name threetip sagebrush. It is native to western North America from British Columbia to Nevada and Montana to Colorado. It covers about 8.4 million acres (3.4 million hectares) of the Rocky Mountains and Great Basin.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["Threetip Sagebrush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Artemisia tripartita"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you are cultivating it indoors or in drier climates, misting regularly with rainwater or distilled water can help maintain its necessary moisture levels. Ensure that the lichen is never submerged in water, as excess moisture can lead to decay. It thrives best in humid environments, so placing it in a terrarium or near a humidifier can effectively simulate its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobaria scrobiculata requires filtered light rather than direct sunlight. This lichen thrives in dappled shade environments, mimicking conditions found under forest canopies. Direct sunlight can damage it, leading to dehydration and potential death. It’s important to maintain a balance of light that supports photosynthesis while avoiding exposure that might dry out or harm the lichen."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Lobaria scrobiculata as lichens generally maintain their own natural structure and shape. However, if portions of the lichen appear to be dead or decaying, they can be gently removed to prevent any potential spread of damage. It's crucial to handle it gently due to its delicate nature. When removing dead parts, ensure that healthy sections are not harmed. Typically, assessment and removal of unwanted sections can be performed once or twice a year, depending on the condition of the lichen."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Textured Lung Lichen","description":"Lobaria scrobiculata, commonly known as the textured lungwort, is a large foliose, epiphytic lichen.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Grey-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["USA","Europe"],"other_name":["Textured Lung Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore","Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lobaria scrobiculata"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease entry. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14967,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cunninghamia lanceolata, commonly known as Chinese fir, prefers well-drained soil and should not be waterlogged. It is important to maintain evenly moist soil conditions, especially during its establishment phase. Water the plant regularly but ensure that the soil doesn't become saturated. Once established, the Chinese fir is relatively drought-tolerant but benefits from occasional deep watering during dry periods. Allow the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Adjust the frequency of watering according to the climate and weather conditions, increasing it during hotter periods and reducing during wet seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cunninghamia lanceolata thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. Full sun helps maintain a dense, healthy crown and promotes faster growth. However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hot, arid regions where some afternoon shelter may prevent leaf scorch. Ensure the planting location provides ample sunlight exposure to encourage strong development, though the tree also adapts to less-than-ideal light conditions without significant detriment, making it versatile for various landscapes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cunninghamia lanceolata is typically minimal, as the tree maintains a natural conical shape. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health and appearance. Occasionally, thinning can help improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, stimulating vigorous growth. For shaping, limit cuts to selectively removing branches to refine the tree's form without causing undue stress. Avoid heavy pruning, as this may affect growth and overall health. Always use clean, sharp tools to ensure clean cuts and reduce the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"China-fir","description":"Cunninghamia is a genus of one or two living species of evergreen coniferous trees in the cypress family Cupressaceae. They are native to China, northern Vietnam and Laos, and perhaps also Cambodia. They may reach 50 m (160 ft) in height. In vernacular use, it is most often known as Cunninghamia, but is also sometimes called \"China-fir\" (though it is not a fir). The genus name Cunninghamia honours Dr. James Cunningham, a British doctor who introduced this species...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Taiwan","Vietnam","Laos"],"other_name":["China-fir"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Cunninghamia lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14173,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Unlike many traditional houseplants, Peltigera membranacea, a type of lichen, requires consistent moisture to thrive. It naturally grows on soils, rocks, or mossy forest floors where it can absorb water from rain or mist. When cultivating it indoors or in a garden, ensure that the substrate remains damp without being waterlogged. Mist the lichen regularly to mimic its natural environment, especially in dry conditions. However, ensure good air circulation to prevent mold. Avoid using mineral-rich water, as lichens are sensitive to pollution and chemicals. Maintain a humid environment to replicate its native habitat conditions, which are typically cool and moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"For Peltigera membranacea, an environment that mimics its natural habitat is crucial for its wellbeing. This lichen usually thrives in shaded or semi-shaded areas, often found under the canopy of forests where it receives dappled sunlight. If cultivated indoors, it should not be placed under direct, intense light, which can cause desiccation and hinder growth. An east or north-facing window, where it can receive indirect light, but remains protected from harsh midday sun, is ideal. Outdoor cultivation should ensure shaded spots, perhaps under trees or structures, to keep the lichen from too much exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Peltigera membranacea is not a typical requirement as it is for more traditional garden plants. However, maintaining its health may require occasional removal of any dead or damaged parts. Carefully inspect for areas that appear brown or brittle and gently trim them away with scissors or snips. Pruning is generally done to promote healthy growth and prevent decay, which can spread and affect the entire lichen structure. Always handle with care, as lichens are delicate. Regularly cleaning its growing medium and controlling competing plant growth can also be considered a part of maintenance and care."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"membranous pelt lichen","description":"Peltigera membranacea is a species of lichenized fungus in the family Peltigeraceae. It has a foliose growth pattern, with what appear to be veins in the leaf-like parts, but these do not have a vascular function.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["membranous pelt lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Peltigera membranacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Slightly acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the plant is placed in an area that has ample sunlight exposure but monitor the leaves for signs of sunburn and adjust its position or provide shade when necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Wigandia urens involves removing dead or damaged branches and controlling its size and shape. This can be done in early spring before new growth starts or late winter in milder climates. Regular trimming helps maintain a bushy and compact structure, encouraging more blooms and robust growth. Remove any suckers at the base if you want to maintain a tree-like form. Wear gloves while pruning to protect against the irritant hairs on the plant, and sanitize your tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fiberglass plant","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["fiberglass plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Wigandia urens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14568,"attracts":["Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bouteloua hirsuta, commonly known as Hairy Grama, is a drought-tolerant grass that requires minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, water it regularly to help the root system develop. After establishment, reduce watering frequency, as this plant thrives in dry conditions. It is important to avoid overwatering; allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions will prevent root rot and other moisture-related diseases. In regions with regular rainfall, supplementary watering may not be necessary. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to mimic its natural arid habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bouteloua hirsuta prefers full sun exposure to thrive, as it is naturally adapted to open and sunlit habitats such as prairies and grasslands. Ensure it receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and health. Insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced vigor. In regions where intense heat could be a concern, slight afternoon shade can be beneficial but is generally not necessary. Planting it in a south-facing position with a clear exposure to sunlight will support its typical growth habits and resilience."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bouteloua hirsuta is generally minimal and is mainly done to maintain its appearance and remove any dead or damaged foliage. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Trim back the previous year’s growth to a few inches above the ground. This not only tidy the plant’s appearance but also encourages vigorous new growth. Throughout the growing season, you can remove any diseased or dead blades as needed. Pruning is more about maintaining plant health and less about altering its natural structure which is typically left to grow freely."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hairy grama","description":"Bouteloua hirsuta, commonly known as hairy grama, is a perennial short prairie grass that is native throughout much of North America, including the Great Plains and Canadian Prairies region, as well as Mexico and Guatemala.","family":null,"flower_color":"re,yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hairy grama"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Bouteloua hirsuta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14866,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Krameria lanceolata, commonly known as trailing krameria or ratany, is a hardy plant that is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. When cultivating this plant, it is best to mimic its natural conditions by allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided since it can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, ensuring good drainage. During the growing season, water sparingly and reduce the frequency even further in the winter months when the plant is dormant. Monitor the soil moisture to adjust watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Krameria lanceolata thrives in full sun conditions, reflecting its adaptation to open, arid landscapes. For best growth and flowering, it should be situated in a location where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Inadequate sunlight can result in reduced vigor and fewer flowers. If full sun exposure is not feasible, this plant can tolerate partial shade, though its performance might not be optimal. Whether planted in containers or directly in the ground, ensuring adequate sunlight exposure is crucial for this sun-loving species to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Krameria lanceolata is not typically necessary due to its relatively low-growth habit. However, pruning can be employed to maintain its shape or remove any dead or damaged stems. The best time for pruning is during the early spring before the new growth begins. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to cut back any overgrown branches, and remove any dead or diseased parts to prevent the spread of pathogens. Take care not to prune too aggressively, as this can stress the plant. Overall, light pruning can encourage a healthy and more aesthetically pleasing growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Trailing Rhatany","description":"Krameria lanceolata, commonly called trailing krameria, is a flowering plant in the rhatany family (Krameriaceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15560,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus scopulorum, commonly known as Rocky Mountain Juniper, requires minimal watering once established. This plant is drought-tolerant, thriving best in dry, well-drained soil. During the first year after planting, water regularly to help it establish a strong root system. Once established, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other health issues. In the hotter months, you may need to water slightly more frequently, but generally, rainfall will provide sufficient moisture for these resilient plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus scopulorum thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun daily. Insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse foliage and reduced vigor. Ideal for open, sunny locations, this juniper is tolerant of poorer soils and windy conditions, making it suitable for exposed sites. However, ensure it does not receive too much shade as this may lead to weaker growth and more susceptibility to diseases. Planting in an area with good air circulation is beneficial to its overall health and growth performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus scopulorum involves removing any dead or diseased branches to maintain health and appearance. This should ideally be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid heavy pruning as junipers do not recover well when cut back into old wood. Lightly trim to shape and control size, ensuring cuts are made close to a lateral branch or just above a leaf node to promote healthy regrowth. Regular monitoring and selective pruning help maintain the desired form while allowing for natural growth habits."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rocky Mountain Juniper","description":"Juniperus scopulorum (Rocky Mountain juniper) is a species of juniper native to western North America, in Canada in British Columbia and southwest Alberta, in the United States from Washington east to North Dakota, south to Arizona and also locally western Texas, and northernmost Mexico from Sonora east to Coahuila. It grows at altitudes of 500–2,700 metres (1,600–8,900 ft) on dry soils, often together with other juniper species. \"Scopulorum\" means \"of the mountains.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Rocky Mountain Juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus scopulorum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14370,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oxalis glabra prefers moderately moist soil, so water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. Over-watering should also be avoided, as it can lead to root rot. Aim to maintain consistent moisture during the growing season and reduce watering in the winter when the plant's growth slows. If grown in pots, ensure there is good drainage to prevent water from accumulating at the bottom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis glabra thrives in bright but indirect sunlight. It can tolerate full sun, especially in cooler climates, but in hotter areas, some shade during the midday sun is appreciated to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a window where it can receive plenty of natural light, such as an east-facing or west-facing window. If the plant doesn't get enough light, it may become leggy as it stretches towards the light source. Avoid placing it in deep shade as its growth will suffer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oxalis glabra involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and maintain its appearance. Trim back any overgrown stems to keep the plant compact and bushy. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation around the plant, which can prevent fungal diseases. It's also a good idea to remove faded flowers to extend the blooming period. Conduct pruning during its active growth phase, usually in spring and summer, to avoid shocking the plant. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to make precise cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Carpet Sorrel","description":"Oxalis glabra is a member of the wood-sorrel family, Oxalidaceae. It is only one of the 800 total species belonging to this family. The plant is commonly known as \"finger-leaf\" due to its trifoliate leaf structure. This trifoliate structure can be seen in variations throughout all members of the Oxalis genus. However, the particularly narrow leaflets of the glabra plant look more like fingers rather than a common clover. The plant is native to South Africa...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Carpet Sorrel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Oxalis glabra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15762,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ipomopsis longiflora, commonly known as the longflowered ipomopsis, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering. It's best to water this plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure good drainage and to avoid waterlogging the soil. During periods of drought, the plant can withstand dry conditions due to its hardy nature. Water the plant every couple of weeks during dry spells, but reduce watering during rainy periods to prevent excessive moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomopsis longiflora thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is adapted to open, sunny environments, making it ideal for rock gardens, dry slopes, or other sun-drenched areas in your garden. If planted in an area with partial shade, it may result in leggy growth and reduce the number of blooms. To ensure the best bloom performance and a healthy plant, place it in a location where it can soak up ample sunlight throughout the day. Adjust the planting site if the plant seems to underperform in its current position."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomopsis longiflora is not generally needed for health but can be done to maintain its shape or to prevent self-seeding if that's a concern. Once the blooming period is over, you can deadhead the spent flowers to encourage new growth and prevent the plant from directing energy into seed production. Cut back any stems that appear dead or damaged to improve the plant's appearance and vitality. For a bushier growth, you can pinch back the stems early in the growing season, although this species typically maintains a natural, airy form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flaxflowered Ipomopsis","description":"Ipomopsis longiflora (common name flaxflowered gilia or flaxflowered ipomopsis) is a plant. While it can tolerate short periods of drought, regular watering ensures healthy growth. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry, avoiding waterlogging which can lead to root rot. It is essential to have well-drained soil to prevent standing water around the roots. During periods of extended dry weather, increase the frequency of watering to maintain soil moisture. However, reduce watering in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aunt Lucy (Ellisia nyctelea) thrives best in partial to full shade, making it suitable for woodland gardens or forest edges. It can adapt to dappled sunlight where direct sun rays are filtered through tree canopies. In its natural habitat, it often receives direct sunlight in the morning or late afternoon, with shading during the intense midday sun. Too much direct sunlight can lead to leaf scorch, whereas too little light can impede flowering. Aim to provide a balanced light environment, ensuring the plant receives some relief from the harshest sun rays during peak midday hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ellisia nyctelea is typically not necessary since it is an annual plant; however, it can be beneficial to prune away any dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. You can also pinch back the stem tips to encourage bushier growth and to control the plant's spread. Removing spent flowers can help prolong the blooming period by preventing seed formation, allowing the plant to focus energy on producing new flowers. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Aunt Lucy","description":"Ellisia is a genus of flowering plants in the forget-me-not family (Boraginaceae), containing the sole species Ellisia nyctelea. It is native to North America, where it is also known as Aunt Lucy, false babyblueeyes, and waterpod. The genus was named in honor of British naturalist John Ellis, a contemporary of, and correspondent to, Carl Linnaeus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Aunt Lucy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ellisia nyctelea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is essential to water the plant regularly, keeping the soil slightly damp but not waterlogged. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through fall, Ixora benefits from more frequent watering. In contrast, reduce watering slightly in winter but never allow the soil to dry out completely. Always check the topsoil for dryness before watering, and adjust based on the local climate and indoor humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ixora coccinea thrives in full sun to partial shade, needing a minimum of 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce its vibrant flowers. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching, but generally, more sunlight results in denser growth and more prolific blooming. When grown indoors, place the plant near a bright, sunny window to ensure adequate light. Lack of sunlight may result in sparse flowering and leggy growth, so assess the light conditions to make necessary adjustments for optimal plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ixora coccinea is not only beneficial for maintaining its compact shape but also for encouraging healthier, bushier growth. The best time to prune is right after the plant has finished blooming, typically in late spring or early summer. Focus on removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches, and cut back any leggy stems to maintain the desired size and shape. Pruning also helps to increase airflow within the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Use clean, sharp tools, and make cuts just above a node to encourage new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Jungle flame","description":"Ixora coccinea (also known as jungle geranium, flame of the woods or jungle flame) is a species of flowering plant in the Rubiaceae family. It is the national flower of Suriname.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Sri Lanka"],"other_name":["Jungle flame"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ixora coccinea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14265,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Hygrophorus roseibrunneus, like most fungi, does not require watering in the traditional sense as plants do. Instead, it thrives in moist environments typically found in forested regions with heavy leaf litter. To simulate ideal conditions, ensure the substrate is consistently moist but not waterlogged. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15561,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Larix sibirica, commonly known as Siberian larch, prefers well-drained soil and, once established, is quite drought-tolerant. However, during its first few years after planting, it requires consistent watering to help establish its root system. Water the tree thoroughly, aiming for deep irrigation rather than shallow, frequent watering. During periods of prolonged drought or extreme heat, ensure to water the tree more frequently. Avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. Monitoring the soil moisture, especially during the growing season, will help maintain the right balance of hydration."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Larix sibirica thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It prefers open areas where it can receive ample sunlight, which is essential for its photosynthesis and overall growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, its growth may be slower, and the tree might not reach its full potential. Consider planting this larch in an exposed site to ensure it receives the maximum sunlight available. Adequate sunlight also helps the tree develop its characteristic vibrant autumn colors and supports its deciduous needle cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Larix sibirica is generally not necessary, as the tree naturally develops a pleasing form. However, light pruning can be performed to remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches, which should be done during late fall or early spring when the tree is dormant. Make clean cuts close to the trunk without leaving stubs, and avoid removing more than a third of the tree's branches in a single season. Regular inspections for any crowded or crossed branches can also help maintain tree health and structure, reducing potential issues with pest infestations or diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian larch","description":"Larix sibirica, the Siberian larch or Russian larch, is a frost-hardy tree native to western Russia, from close to the Finnish border east to the Yenisei valley in central Siberia, where it hybridises with the Dahurian larch L. gmelinii of eastern Siberia; the hybrid is known as Larix × czekanowskii.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Russia","Eastern Siberia","Mongolia","China"],"other_name":["Siberian larch"],"pest_susceptibility":["Larch sawfly","Larch adelgid"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Larix sibirica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly to maintain slightly moist soil, particularly during dry spells or hot summer months. However, ensure the plant is not sitting in waterlogged conditions, as this can lead to root rot. A layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. Generally, watering about once a week or when the top inch of soil feels dry is a good practice for maintaining healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum drummondii thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to encourage robust growth and abundant flowering. However, it can tolerate some light shade, particularly in hotter climates where partial shading during the afternoon can prevent overheating. When planting, consider spots that offer morning sunlight and moderate afternoon shade. Adequate sunlight exposure is crucial to ensure the plant produces its signature attractive blooms during the late summer and fall seasons."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is important for managing the growth of Symphyotrichum drummondii and can encourage more vigorous flowering. After the blooming period, deadhead spent flowers to prevent self-seeding and encourage additional blooms. In late fall or early spring, cut back the stems to about 4-6 inches from the ground to manage plant shape and remove any dead or damaged stems. Additionally, occasional thinning of the plant can improve air circulation, helping to prevent fungal diseases. Pruning helps to keep the plant looking neat and promotes healthier growth in the upcoming season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Drummond's aster","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Violet","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Drummond's aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum drummondii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
