{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15861,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron canadense, commonly known as the Rhodora, requires consistent moisture to thrive. Water the plant deeply and regularly, especially during dry periods. The soil should be kept moist but not waterlogged; aim for slightly acidic, well-draining soil to prevent root rot. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's water needs decrease. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain even soil temperature. Always adjust watering based on local climate and seasonal weather conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron canadense prefers a location that offers partial shade to full sun, although it performs best with morning sunlight and protection from the harsh afternoon sun. The plant needs a few hours of direct sunlight each day to flower profusely, but too much intense light can scorch the leaves. In hotter climates, providing some light dappled shade during the heat of the day can protect the plant's foliage and stress. In cooler climates, more sun is generally beneficial. Ensure the planting site is open enough for good air circulation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rhododendron canadense should be done in early spring after blooming to encourage healthy growth and a good shape. Remove dead or diseased wood and any branches that are crossing or rubbing against each other. This plant typically requires minimal pruning, so focus on maintaining its natural shape. Avoid heavy pruning as it can impact the flowering next season. Thin out overcrowded branches to maintain airflow through the plant to prevent fungal issues. Sterilize pruning tools before use to minimize the risk of transmitting diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rhodora","description":"Rhododendron canadense, the rhodora, is a deciduous flowering shrub that is native to northeastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Canada","United States"],"other_name":["Rhodora"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root Rot","Powdery Mildew","Leaf Spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron canadense"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The plant prefers well-drained soil and should be watered sparingly to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In the dormant winter months, reduce the frequency of watering significantly. Overwatering is a common mistake with this plant, so ensure that the soil is not consistently moist and that the pot or garden area has adequate drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This species of milkweed thrives in full sun conditions, meaning it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. It can tolerate some partial shade, particularly in very hot climates, but too much shade will result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Ideally, plant Asclepias brachystephana in a location with unobstructed access to morning sunlight, which is less intense. If potted indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to maximize sunlight exposure. Adequate sunlight ensures robust growth and encourages prolific flowering, attracting pollinators."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias brachystephana involves removing dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth and potential reblooming. This should ideally be done in early spring when new growth begins to appear. Light trimming can also be performed after the flowering season to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Removal of seed pods may be necessary if you wish to prevent the plant from self-seeding. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid introducing disease, and minimize pruning during the plant's active growing season to avoid stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bract milkweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["bract milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias brachystephana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14969,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Packera obovata, commonly known as round-leaved ragwort, prefers consistent moisture in well-drained soil but is adaptable to various conditions. It thrives in average to medium moisture environments, and although it tolerates dry periods, it should not be overwatered. During hot summer months, regular watering may be necessary to maintain the plant's health. Smaller, more frequent watering can help prevent waterlogging, especially in less well-draining soils. Monitor the soil to ensure it stays moist but not soggy, and reduce watering during periods of heavy rain or in cooler months when growth is less active."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Packera obovata grows best in partial to full shade, making it ideal for shaded gardens or woodland settings. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, too much can cause stress and lead to scorched leaves, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, it should receive dappled sunlight or be planted in an area with morning sun and afternoon shade. If planted in deep shade, it may not bloom as prolifically. Adjusting the plant's position in the garden by observing how it responds to different sunlight exposures can help achieve optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Packera obovata is mainly about maintaining its shape and promoting vitality. You can remove spent or damaged foliage to encourage fresh growth, doing so in early spring before the growing season starts. Deadheading the flowers after they fade can prevent self-seeding and encourage a tidier appearance. Additionally, cutting back the plant in late fall or after the first frost helps prepare it for winter dormancy. However, avoid excessive pruning as this might stress the plant. Always use clean and sharp tools to prevent any damage or disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"roundleaf ragwort","description":"Packera obovata, the roundleaf ragwort or spoon-leaved ragwort, is an erect perennial herb native to Eastern North America. It was previously called Senecio obovatus. Basal and lower leaves are obovate with toothed margins, while upper leaves are pinnately divided. The ray flowers are yellow and the disk flowers orange-yellow, the inflorescences being held well above the foliage.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["roundleaf ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Packera obovata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14175,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parmelia saxatilis, commonly known as the \"crottle\" lichen, requires minimal watering in cultivation as it naturally thrives in arid and rocky environments. Typically, these lichens obtain moisture from rainfall and atmospheric humidity, so no additional watering is usually necessary when growing them outdoors. If cultivating indoors in a drier environment, occasional light misting may suffice to simulate their natural surroundings. It's crucial to avoid overwatering as lichens are highly susceptible to rotting in persistently moist conditions. Allow them to dry out completely between waterings to maintain their health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parmelia saxatilis thrives in locations that receive moderate sunlight. It's best suited for partially shaded areas, mimicking its natural habitat where it typically grows on rocks and trees in partially lit environments. Too much direct, harsh sunlight may cause desiccation or damage to the lichen, whereas too little light can impede its photosynthesis and metabolic functions. Ensuring a suitable balance by providing dappled sunlight or filtered light conditions will support optimal growth. When indoors, placing it near a window with indirect light is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or trimming Parmelia saxatilis is not generally required as lichens naturally form their own structures without human intervention. If managing growth or aesthetics, you can gently remove any debris or dead material using tweezers or small, clean scissors. It's important to handle them delicately to avoid damaging the lichen's body or thallus. Regular inspection can help ensure healthy growth and prevent issues with moss or algae overgrowth. Any pruning should be done very sparingly, as lichens grow slowly and are sensitive to environmental conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Salted Shield Lichen","description":"Parmelia saxatilis, commonly known as the salted shield lichen or crottle, is a species of foliose lichen in the family Parmeliaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Salted Shield Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Parmelia saxatilis"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This prevents tearing and minimizes damage. Additionally, prune back any fronds that are encroaching on paths or other plants. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14266,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Inocybe geophylla, commonly known as the earthy inocybe, is a type of mushroom rather than a plant suitable for domestic cultivation or care. Thus, it does not require a watering guide in the traditional sense of houseplants. In its natural environment, this fungus benefits from moist habitats typical in its native wooded ecosystems where humidity and soil moisture support its growth. If found growing in a garden setting, it will not need additional watering as it relies on the natural ground moisture or existing irrigation provided to surrounding plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Inocybe geophylla typically grows in shaded wooded areas. It thrives on the forest floor, where it receives dappled sunlight or indirect light filtered through tree canopies. Direct sunlight is not ideal as it can dry out the habitat it prefers; thus, it thrives in shaded, humid environments. When observing or studying it in nature, ensure the area mimics its native conditions, avoiding open and excessively sunlit areas. Preserving the natural tree coverage aids in maintaining its suitable growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a wild mushroom species, Inocybe geophylla does not require or benefit from pruning. Unlike plants, mushrooms grow from mycelium, a fungal network that doesn't need to be pruned. This mushroom should be left undisturbed in its natural habitat. Removing fungi like Inocybe geophylla without a specific purpose, such as scientific study or conservation control, might disrupt the fungal ecology and could potentially remove a food source for wildlife. It’s important to allow it to complete its natural lifecycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Fibrecap","description":"Inocybe geophylla, commonly known as the earthy inocybe, common white inocybe or white fibercap, is a poisonous mushroom of the genus Inocybe. It is drought-tolerant and should not be overwatered. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In general, moderate watering once every 7-10 days is sufficient. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other diseases, so ensure the plant is never sitting in waterlogged soil for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias engelmanniana thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight a day to grow optimally. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun will promote the best flowering and growth. If planted in partially shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensure that the planting location receives unobstructed sunlight, particularly in the morning hours, to support healthy development. Too much shade can lead to poor performance and reduced vigor in this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias engelmanniana should be done to remove dead or damaged stems and to control its size and shape, if necessary. Prune dead stems back to the ground in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This encourages fresh, healthy growth in the spring. If the plant becomes leggy or out of shape, you can trim back the stems by about one-third to encourage bushier growth. Avoid pruning in late fall as it can lead to dieback. Also, consider leaving some seed pods through winter for wildlife and visual interest."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Engelmann's milkweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Engelmann's milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias engelmanniana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The best time to prune is in early spring before the plant begins new growth. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts just above a node or branching point. Remove no more than one-third of the plant at a time to avoid stressing it. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to promote new blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Pruning can also help improve air circulation within the plant, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"desert rosemallow","description":"Hibiscus coulteri, the desert rosemallow, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15665,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernonia noveboracensis, or New York Ironweed, thrives in consistently moist conditions and enjoys regular watering. During its growing season, ensure that the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, watering it deeply once or twice a week depending on rainfall and humidity. Avoid letting the soil completely dry out, as this plant prefers a somewhat damp environment. In extremely hot or dry weather, increase the frequency of watering to maintain moisture levels. During the winter months, reduce the watering frequency, allowing the natural precipitation to suffice unless experiencing drought-like conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"New York Ironweed flourishes best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to support vigorous growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, too little sunlight may cause the plant to become lanky and reduce its bloom production. If planting in areas with intense sunlight, occasional afternoon shade can help prevent heat stress. However, in general, position this plant in a sunny spot to ensure it reaches its full potential in terms of height and blossom development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Vernonia noveboracensis during late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove old, spent stems to the base to encourage healthy new shoots. This not only helps in maintaining the individual's shape and size but also in promoting vigorous growth and prolific flowering when the season arrives. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy during the growing season, you can cut back the stems to encourage bushier growth. Always use sharp, clean pruning tools to prevent disease and make clean cuts just above leaf nodes for best results."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"New York ironweed","description":"Vernonia noveboracensis (New York ironweed or vein-leaf hawkweed) is a plant in the daisy family, Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14572,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Linum rigidum, commonly known as stiff-stem flax, requires moderate watering. It is essential to keep the soil slightly moist, but not waterlogged. During periods of active growth, typically spring through early summer, make sure to water the plant whenever the top inch of soil feels dry. In drier seasons or in well-draining soil, the frequency of watering may increase. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering to allow the plant to rest, ensuring you only water if the soil becomes completely dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Linum rigidum thrives in bright environments and prefers full sun conditions. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce its best blooms and maintain its structural health. In regions with intense summer heat, the plant may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window with ample light. Ensuring adequate sunlight helps the plant maintain its vibrant flowering and overall vigour. Too little light may result in leggy growth and poor flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Linum rigidum is generally not intensive but can help maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is best to prune the plant in early spring, just before new growth begins. Trim back any dead or damaged stems to promote vigorous new growth. If the plant becomes too dense, selectively thinning it out will improve air circulation. Deadheading spent flowers will encourage a longer blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Flax","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Yellow Flax"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Linum rigidum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize harm to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Asian bayberry","description":"Nageia nagi, the Asian bayberry, is plant species in the family Podocarpaceae named by Carl Peter Thunberg. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14267,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Inocybe sororia, a type of mushroom, does not require traditional plant care like watering, as it naturally grows in moist environments such as forests or grasslands. The key is to maintain a humid environment if attempting to grow it indoors or in controlled environments. Mist the area lightly to mimic rain and maintain moisture in the soil substrate, ensuring it is not waterlogged, which could lead to decay or mold growth. The environment should stay consistently damp to support the mushroom's growth cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Inocybe sororia prefers low-light conditions typical of its natural forest floor or grassland habitats. If grown indoors, it should be placed in a shaded area or under indirect light, away from direct sunlight, which can dry out the substrate and hinder mushroom development. Providing a light source that mimics the dappled light of a forest canopy can help encourage healthy growth while maintaining a humid and cool environment similar to their natural ecosystem."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mushrooms like Inocybe sororia do not require pruning as traditional plants do. Insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias glaucescens is not strictly necessary, but it can help promote a tidier appearance and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Cut back any dead or damaged stems and leaves to the base. Throughout the growing season, remove any spent flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively and to encourage a repeat bloom. Be sure to wear gloves when pruning, as the milky sap can irritate the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"nodding milkweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["nodding milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias glaucescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15765,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Malva alcea, commonly known as Hollyhock Mallow, prefers a moderate watering regimen. It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During hot summer months, you may need to water more frequently, but reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows. Be mindful of signs of overwatering, such as yellowing leaves or root rot. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vibrant blooms and healthy growth. In areas with intense afternoon sun, it may benefit from some light shade during the peak heat of the day to prevent wilting. However, too much shade may reduce flowering. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to ensure it receives adequate light. Insufficient sunlight can result in spindly growth and fewer flowers, so adjust its placement as needed for optimal light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malva alcea involves trimming back the plant after the flowering season to encourage bushier growth and more blooms in the future. Remove any dead or damaged stems at any time, as well as faded flowers to promote continuous blooming. In late fall, you can cut the plant down to about a third of its size or to ground level, depending on your preference and climate. This pruning helps in managing its size and ensures healthy growth in the spring. Clean pruning tools with alcohol to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Greater Musk-mallow","description":"Malva alcea (greater musk-mallow, cut-leaved mallow, vervain mallow or hollyhock mallow) is a plant in the mallow family native to southwestern, central and eastern Europe and southwestern Asia, from Spain north to southern Sweden and east to Russia and Turkey.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Greater Musk-mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Malva alcea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, especially when the plant is not actively growing in the winter months. During the hot summer months, you may need to water more frequently to keep up with evaporation. Mulching can be beneficial to maintain moisture in hotter climates but ensure the mulch doesn’t touch the plant’s stem directly to avoid rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Monarda citriodora thrives best in full sun, which facilitates healthy growth and abundant flowering. It requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can lead to reduced blooms and weaker growth. If you are growing this plant in a region with intensely hot summers, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. However, ensuring ample morning sun is critical for optimal health and floral display. Positioning the plant in a spot with good air circulation and sufficient sunlight will also help prevent mildew issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Monarda citriodora helps to promote bushy growth and prevent legginess. It’s best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Trim the plant back to about one-third of its size to encourage more robust growth in the upcoming season. Deadheading spent flowers throughout the growing season will prolong blooming and enhance the plant’s appearance. Cut back the plant at the end of the season in autumn or early winter to maintain tidiness and prepare it for the winter months. Removing diseased or damaged stems throughout the year helps maintain the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lemon beebalm","description":"Monarda citriodora is a species of flowering plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae, that is native much of the United States and Mexico. Common names include lemon beebalm, lemon mint (this may also apply to Mentha citrata or Melissa officinalis) and purple horsemint. When crushed, the leaves emit an odor reminiscent of lemons. This odor is sometimes described as more resembling oregano, especially late in the season. Its purple flowers are highly attractive to butterflies, bees...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["lemon beebalm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Monarda citriodora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14673,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"As Panaeolus semiovatus is a type of mushroom rather than a traditional plant, it doesn't require typical watering as houseplants do. Mushrooms thrive in humid environments. To cultivate this species, maintain a high humidity level around 80-90%, often achieved through misting the air around the growing area or using a humidity tent. It is crucial to keep the substrate or growing medium damp but not overly saturated with direct water, as this can lead to other fungal issues or growth of unwanted molds."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panaeolus semiovatus, like most mushrooms, does not require direct sunlight and instead thrives in low-light or shaded conditions. This species is often found growing in moist environments with indirect light. Artificial lighting, such as fluorescent or LED lights, can be used if growing indoors, but the light should be kept mild and diffused. Intense direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and provide excessive heat, inhibiting growth and potentially damaging the mushroom mycelium."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Panaeolus semiovatus, as it is a mushroom species rather than a leafy plant. Management involves careful harvesting instead. Once the mushrooms reach full size and the caps separate from the stems, they can be gently removed by twisting the base and pulling them out of the substrate. Properly harvested mushrooms do not require further pruning or trimming and should be done promptly to ensure quality and avoid over-mature mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shiny Mottlegill","description":"Panaeolus semiovatus var. semiovatus, also known as Panaeolus semiovatus and Anellaria separata, is a medium-sized buff colored mushroom/toadstool that grows on horse dung, and has black spores. While some guides list this species as edible, a few people experience gastric upset after consumption. Its common names are the shiny mottlegill, or egghead mottlegill.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Worldwide"],"other_name":["Shiny Mottlegill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Panaeolus semiovatus"],"soil":["Moist","Rich in organic matter"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14972,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Equisetum pratense, commonly known as shade horsetail, thrives in consistently moist soil. It is important to keep the soil damp, especially during its growing season, which is typically in spring and summer. Ensure the soil doesn't dry out completely as this plant prefers wet conditions. However, avoid waterlogging, as too much water can lead to root rot. A good practice is to inspect the soil regularly and water when the top layer feels slightly dry, ensuring moisture reaches deeper roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Equisetum pratense prefers a location that offers partial to full shade, mimicking its natural habitat in moist, shaded environments like forest margins. While it can tolerate some sunlight, too much direct, intense light can cause the plant to dry out and become stressed. If planting outdoors, choose a spot that receives dappled sunlight or is shaded by taller plants. Indoors, it should be placed in a spot away from direct sunlight, ensuring the plant remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Equisetum pratense isn't generally necessary for the plant's health but can be done for aesthetic reasons or to control its spread, as it can be invasive. If desired, trim back dead or damaged stems at the base whenever they appear. Early spring, before new growth begins, is an ideal time for extensive pruning if you wish to thin the plant or manage its size. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission and encourage healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"meadow horsetail","description":"Equisetum pratense, commonly known as meadow horsetail, shade horsetail or shady horsetail, is a plant species belonging to the division of horsetails (Equisetophyta). Shade horsetail can be commonly found in forests with tall trees or very thick foliage that can provide shade. They also tend to grow closer and thicker around streams, ponds and rivers.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["meadow horsetail"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Equisetum pratense"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14771,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lygodesmia aphylla, commonly known as the skeleton plant, is adapted to dry, arid environments and therefore requires minimal watering. It is drought-tolerant and can survive with very infrequent waterings. It is vital to ensure that the soil has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, you can water the plant sparingly, but it's best to let the soil completely dry out between watering sessions. In periods of dormancy or cooler months, reduce watering even further, potentially ceasing it altogether depending on your climate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lygodesmia aphylla is well adapted to full sun conditions and thrives in bright, direct sunlight. It ideally requires at least six hours of sunlight a day to maintain its growth and flowering. In its natural habitat, it is accustomed to the intense and direct sun of arid regions, so replicating these conditions will support its health and vigor. If grown in partial shade, the plant may become leggy or fail to flower as profusely. Ensure that the plant is positioned in a location where it can receive ample direct sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lygodesmia aphylla is minimal and primarily focused on maintaining the plant's health and shape. You should remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves to encourage new growth and prevent disease. Pruning is best done in early spring before new growth starts. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make neat cuts and avoid damaging the plant. This practice not only helps to keep the plant looking tidy but also promotes better air circulation and reduces the risk of fungal infections. Avoid excessive pruning as it can weaken the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rose rush","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Grayish green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["rose rush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Lygodesmia aphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15766,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Begonia gracilis prefers consistently moist soil, but it is crucial to avoid waterlogging which could lead to root rot. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Always use room temperature water to prevent shocking the plant's roots. It is best to water thoroughly until excess water drains out of the pot’s drainage holes, ensuring even moisture throughout the soil. In the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering, as the plant's growth slows and it requires less moisture. Maintaining high humidity around the plant is also beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Begonia gracilis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch its leaves, so it's best placed near an east or north-facing window or in a location with filtered sunlight. If the plant receives too much direct sun, you may notice the leaves turning brown or developing sunburn marks. In contrast, insufficient light can result in leggy growth and fewer blooms. Artificial grow lights can be a helpful supplement if natural light is inadequate. Adjust the plant’s position according to seasonal light changes to maintain optimal light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Begonia gracilis promotes a bushier appearance and removes dead or yellowing leaves that can harbor pests or disease. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to trim back leggy stems and spent flowers. This should ideally be done in the growing season, which is spring and summer. Be cautious not to over-prune, as the plant can become stressed. Remove no more than a third of the plant at a time, ensuring healthy new growth can emerge. Pruning also helps improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hollyhock Begonia","description":"Begonia gracilis is a plant species in the family Begoniaceae. It is a small herb widespread in the mountains of Mexico, from Chihuahua to Chiapas, often growing in protected locations in shaded areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Hollyhock Begonia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Botrytis blight","Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Begonia gracilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15170,"attracts":["Wildlife"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex jamesii, commonly known as James's sedge, prefers consistently moist to wet soil. Ensure the soil is well-draining yet retains moisture by using a rich organic mulch or compost. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, to maintain soil moisture. However, avoid waterlogging, which can harm the plant's roots. It's essential to check the soil surface; it should feel slightly damp to the touch, but not soggy. Adjust your watering frequency based on the climate, as this plant thrives with different watering needs in varying temperatures and rainfall conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"James's sedge thrives in partial to full shade but can tolerate some morning sun. It mimics its native woodland habitat where dappled sunlight filters through tree canopies. Ensure it doesn’t receive harsh, direct afternoon sunlight, which could stress the plant. Ideal conditions include beneath deciduous trees or in shaded areas of the garden that receive indirect light. If you live in a particularly bright area, using some covers like garden fabric or additional plant canopy can provide the shade necessary to protect Carex jamesii from excessive sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex jamesii involves removing old or damaged foliage to maintain its appearance and health. During early spring, trim back any dead or brown blades from the previous growth to encourage new shoots. This may involve cutting these sections down to the base to promote fresh growth. Additionally, periodically removing any spent seed heads will help keep the plant tidy and focused on foliage growth. Be cautious not to cut too aggressively; maintaining a natural look with some older foliage can be beneficial for the plant's health and habitat value."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"James' Sedge","description":"Carex jamesii is a sedge native to North America from Minnesota east to New York and south to Oklahoma and South Carolina. It occurs in mesic hardwood forests and flowers from early May to mid July. For its genus, it is a distinctive species when in flower. It has two to four perigynia that are subtended by leaf-like pistillate scales. Its seeds are dispersed by ants.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["James' Sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Carex jamesii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15463,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lycium carolinianum, commonly known as Carolina desert-thorn, prefers moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, meaning it does not require frequent irrigation. Water the plant thoroughly when the top 2-3 inches of the soil feel dry to the touch, particularly during periods of extreme heat or drought. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In winter, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy and its water needs decrease significantly. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and suppress weeds."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lycium carolinianum thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth. This exposure encourages healthy flowering and fruiting. While it can tolerate some light shade, its growth and bloom density may be reduced. Plant it in a location that receives full sun to maintain its vigor and bushy appearance. In partial shade, the plant may become leggy and lose its compact form. Positioning it in direct sun also helps with proper water drainage, which is crucial for preventing root diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lycium carolinianum is generally not necessary unless you want to shape the plant or remove dead or diseased wood. If pruning is desired, the best time to do so is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Light pruning can help maintain the desired form and encourage bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent damage and disease transmission. Make cuts just above a leaf node, and be sure not to remove more than a third of the plant's overall size in a single pruning session."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Christmas berry","description":"Lycium carolinianum, commonly known as Carolina desert-thorn or Christmas berry, is a species of flowering plant in the nightshade family, Solanaceae,","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["Christmas berry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lycium carolinianum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15962,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galega officinalis, commonly known as Goat's Rue, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate occasional periods of drought. However, it is important not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Generally, water the plant deeply once or twice a week, ensuring that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. In particularly hot and dry weather, increase the frequency of watering to maintain optimal moisture levels. Reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galega officinalis thrives in full sunlight to partial shade conditions. It performs best when exposed to at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with particularly harsh summer climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from scorching. While it can tolerate partial shade, blooming may be reduced under such conditions. Ideally, choose a location with morning sun and some afternoon shade, especially in warmer climates, to achieve a balanced environment that promotes healthy growth and abundant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galega officinalis is essential to control its growth and encourage more vigorous flowering. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems first. Trim back the remaining stems by about one-third to maintain a compact shape. During the growing season, you can deadhead spent flowers to prolong blooming and prevent self-seeding. If the plant becomes too unruly, cut back after flowering to promote a tidy appearance and stimulate new growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"common milkpea","description":"Galega officinalis, commonly known as galega, goat's-rue, French lilac, Italian fitch, or professor-weed, is an herbaceous plant in the Faboideae subfamily. The plant has been extensively cultivated as a forage crop, an ornamental, a bee plant, and as green manure.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Southwestern Asia"],"other_name":["common milkpea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Galega officinalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14472,"attracts":["Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diospyros texana, commonly known as Texas persimmon, is drought-tolerant once established, requiring minimal watering. When planting initially, provide regular water to establish the root system, particularly during the first growing season. After establishment, water infrequently, as the plant is adapted to survive in dry conditions. Overwatering should be avoided; ensure the soil dries out between watering sessions. During extended dry periods or extreme heat, you may need to water more frequently, but always allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Texas persimmon thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to grow and produce fruit successfully. It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but fruiting and growth may be reduced. Planting in a sunny location will promote a robust structure and healthy foliage. If grown indoors or in a courtyard with less light, ensure it receives as much brightness as possible, potentially moving the plant seasonally to follow sunlight patterns. Protect young plants from extreme summer sun if necessary, gradually acclimatizing them to full sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Diospyros texana during late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Light pruning can also help shape the tree and promote a strong framework. Mature Texas persimmons do not require heavy pruning, and excessive cutting should be avoided to maintain its natural form and encourage fruit production. Pruning should focus on improving airflow through the canopy and removing any suckers that appear at the base. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Persimmon","description":"Diospyros texana is a species of persimmon that is native to central, south and west Texas and southwest Oklahoma in the United States, and eastern Chihuahua, Coahuila, Nuevo León, and Tamaulipas in northeastern Mexico. Common names include Texas persimmon, Mexican persimmon and the more ambiguous \"black persimmon\". It is known in Spanish as chapote, chapote manzano, or chapote prieto, all of which are derived from the Nahuatl word tzapotl. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14268,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Baeospora myosura, commonly known as a mushroom species, does not require watering as a plant does. Instead, it thrives in environments with high humidity. When cultivating or encountering this fungus, focus on maintaining a damp environment by ensuring the substrate remains moist. If using a growing kit or substrate, lightly mist the surface to simulate its natural damp forest floor habitat. Avoid overwatering, which can lead to saturation and inhibit proper growth. Instead, aim for consistent, light moisture to support its development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baeospora myosura does not require direct sunlight like plants; instead, it grows in shaded, forested areas rich in organic matter. When cultivating them, indirect light or a low-light environment is ideal, mimicking the dappled light of a forest floor. Exposing the fungi to excessive direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and the fruiting bodies, hindering growth. Therefore, if grown indoors, a room with indirect light or using low-intensity grow lights is recommended to simulate its natural, subdued lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to fungi like Baeospora myosura as it would be to a plant. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. When planted in a somewhat shadier spot, it may grow slower and develop a less dense foliage. It can adapt to partial shade conditions if necessary, but for optimal health and growth, ensuring abundant sunlight is key. Protect young plants from intense afternoon sun in especially hot climates to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix eriocephala is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote good airflow throughout the plant. Regularly cutting back longer branches will help maintain the desired size and shape. For a more bushy appearance, prune the tips of young branches. Avoid heavy pruning in the middle of the growing season, as it may stress the plant and reduce its vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"heart-leaved willow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["heart-leaved willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salix eriocephala"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning can also be done after the plant has finished flowering to prevent excessive self-seeding, and to maintain a tidy appearance. Do not cut the plant back completely until late fall as the seeds provide food for birds. For taller plants, removing the top few inches can encourage bushier growth. Mulching around the base can help conserve soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. However, ensure the mulch is not directly against the stem to prevent rot. Cut back old stems to the ground at the beginning of the growing season to promote fresh growth and encourage a more compact form. Be cautious not to prune too aggressively, as this can reduce the plant's natural vigor and flowering."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Pink thoroughwort","description":"Fleischmannia incarnata, the pink slender-thoroughwort or pink thoroughwort, is a North American species of flowering plant in the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15464,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Suriana maritima, commonly known as Bay Cedar, is a drought-tolerant plant once established, which means it doesn't require frequent watering. During its initial growth period, provide moderate, even moisture to help establish its roots. Water the plant deeply once a week if there is no rainfall, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. Mature plants can withstand dry conditions for extended periods but appreciate occasional watering during prolonged drought spells. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Suriana maritima thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to perform well. It is tolerant of high temperatures and salty air, making it ideal for coastal regions. While the plant can survive in partial shade, full sun exposure ensures more vigorous growth and better flowering. If growing indoors or in a less sunny area, ensure the plant gets as much light as possible, perhaps by placing it near a south-facing window or supplementing with artificial grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Suriana maritima is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Prune the plant in early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to keep the plant healthy. Trim back any overgrown branches to maintain a compact shape and prevent it from becoming leggy. Light pruning throughout the year can help in maintaining its form and encouraging denser foliage. Be cautious of the plant's milky sap, which can be irritating; wear gloves to protect your skin. Pruning not only helps control the size of the plant but can also stimulate blooming and remove any faded flowers to maintain its ornamental appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"snow-on-the-mountain","description":"Euphorbia marginata (commonly known as snow-on-the-mountain, smoke-on-the-prairie, variegated spurge, or whitemargined spurge) is a small annual in the spurge family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["snow-on-the-mountain"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia marginata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Therefore, it should be positioned in a location that receives indirect light or dappled shade, ensuring it replicates the ambient light conditions of its typical habitat. If grown indoors, placing it near a north-facing window or in a room with filtered light would be ideal, avoiding any harsh sun exposure that can scorch the moss."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally a frequent requirement for Rhytidiadelphus loreus, but occasional trimming may be necessary to maintain its vigor and appearance, particularly if it becomes too dense or overgrown. To prune, gently trim back overgrown sections using scissors, taking care not to disturb the moss's delicate structure. Removing debris or dead sections regularly can also prevent decay and promote healthier growth. Conduct pruning activities with a light hand to avoid damaging the moss, ensuring you maintain its natural form and its ability to thrive in its environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lanky Moss","description":"Rhytidiadelphus loreus, also commonly known as lanky moss, is a nonvascular \"feather moss\" species that is a key component of a healthy, thriving forest ecosystem. Lanky moss grows in North America, Canada and Europe. It is primarily a coastal species that grows in moist, coniferous forests. It grows on decaying logs, the forest floor and as an epiphyte on living trees. Its key function is nitrogen fixation, water retention and temperature insulator.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Lanky Moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spores"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Rhytidiadelphus loreus"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14365,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae, commonly known as the Green-fly Orchid, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It's important to ensure the growing medium is slightly moist but not soggy, as overwatering can lead to root rot. During the growing season, which is typically in the spring and summer, water the plant more frequently, allowing the media to dry out slightly between waterings. In the fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows. It's crucial to use water that is free from salts and chemicals, such as rainwater or distilled water, to prevent damage to the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae thrives in bright but indirect sunlight. It generally prefers light conditions similar to its natural habitat where it grows under tree canopies. Therefore, placing the plant in an area where it can receive dappled sunlight for several hours a day is ideal. Direct sunlight should be avoided, especially the harsh afternoon sun, as it can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, a location near an east or west-facing window works well. If the plant's leaves are dark green, it may require more light, and if they are yellowing, it may need less. Adjust accordingly to maintain healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Epidendrum magnoliae is generally minimal. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves with clean, sharp scissors to maintain plant health and appearance. It's also beneficial to cut off spent flower spikes once the flowers have faded to encourage new growth and prevent nutrient drain on the plant. Be careful not to remove green, healthy leaves as they contribute to photosynthesis. Pruning should be done whenever there's noticeable dead growth, and always use sterile tools to prevent disease spread. Pruning will help keep the plant tidy and focused on producing healthy, new shoots and blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Greenfly Orchid","description":"Epidendrum magnoliae, sometimes called Epidendrum conopseum or the green-fly orchid, is a species of orchid in the genus Epidendrum. It is the most northern-growing epiphytic orchid in North America, being found wild in the southeastern United States from Louisiana to North Carolina, and also in northeastern Mexico (Nuevo León, San Luis Potosí, Tamaulipas).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Cuba"],"other_name":["Greenfly Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Epidendrum magnoliae"],"soil":["Well-drained","Organic-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14366,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calluna vulgaris, commonly known as heather, prefers well-drained, acidic soils. Water the plant regularly but moderately to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry spells or in pots, as it dislikes waterlogged conditions. Take care not to let it dry out completely, particularly in hot weather. Mulching around the base with organic material can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. However, in cool, humid climates, natural rainfall may suffice, and additional watering might not be necessary. Adjust watering frequency based on the season and climate to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calluna vulgaris thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive between 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade would be beneficial to protect the plant from extreme heat. Too much shade may lead to reduced flowering and can cause the plant to become leggy. In cooler climates, full sun is preferable to ensure robust growth and vibrant blooms. It's crucial to strike a balance to provide adequate sunlight without overexposing the plant to harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for Calluna vulgaris to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is in the spring after the last frost, or immediately after flowering in late summer to autumn. Trim the plant lightly by removing faded flowers and cutting back any unruly or woody stems. Avoid cutting into old, brown wood as this can harm the plant. Regular pruning helps to prevent legginess and encourages a bushy, vibrant appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15061,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physalis heterophylla, commonly known as clammy groundcherry, prefers well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. During the growing season, water the plant sufficiently to keep the soil moist but not overly saturated. Be mindful of overwatering as this can lead to root rot. In general, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions is beneficial. During the dormant winter months, reduce the watering frequency significantly, only watering enough to prevent the soil from completely drying out. Ensure that the plant is situated in a pot or ground area with adequate drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, Physalis heterophylla should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to support its growth and flowering. However, it can tolerate some shaded conditions, which might result in less vigorous flowering. When planting, choose a location that allows for adequate morning light exposure with some afternoon shade in hotter climates, preventing leaf scorch. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window will help ensure sufficient light exposure. Always monitor the plant’s response to sunlight and adjust its location as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Physalis heterophylla, pruning is not a significant requirement but can help maintain the plant's shape and promote healthy growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems regularly to encourage new growth. Pruning should be done in early spring before the plant begins its active growth phase. Cutting back overly long stems can prevent the plant from becoming leggy and support a more compact form. Additionally, removing the spent flowers can help concentrate the plant’s energy on root and foliage development. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise, healthy cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"clammy groundcherry","description":"Physalis heterophylla, colloquial name clammy groundcherry, is a herbaceous plant that is a member of the Solanaceae family. It is native to North America, occurring primarily in the eastern United States and Canada. It is known to occur in all contiguous states except for Nevada and California. It is found mainly in habitats such as dry or mesic prairies, gravel hills and rises, sandy or rocky soils, and waste places such as roadsides.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["clammy groundcherry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Physalis heterophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, particularly in spring and early summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Water deeply once a week, providing about 1-2 inches of water, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. During dormant periods in late summer and fall, reduce watering frequency. Clean and disinfect your pruning tools before and after use to prevent spreading any potential pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese peony","description":"Paeonia lactiflora (Chinese peony or common garden peony) is a species of herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the family Paeoniaceae, native to central and eastern Asia from eastern Tibet across northern China to eastern Siberia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Eastern Siberia"],"other_name":["Chinese peony"],"pest_susceptibility":["Gray mold","Powdery mildew","Wilt"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Paeonia lactiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Early spring is the best time for pruning before new growth begins, or in late winter while the plant is dormant. It is best to water deeply, but infrequently, to mimic its natural desert environment. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to the plant. In its natural habitat, it relies on natural rainfall, so supplementary watering may not be necessary unless there is an extended dry period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus havardii thrives in full sun and is well-suited to the bright, intense sunlight typically found in desert and semi-arid climates. Aim to provide at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal growth. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but full sun will bring out its best foliage colors and support its natural, robust growth pattern. In environments with milder climates, make sure it receives ample sunlight to closely mimic its native conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus havardii should primarily be done in the late winter or early spring before new growth appears. This helps maintain the shrub's shape and removes any dead or diseased branches, promoting healthier growth throughout the year. Use sharp, clean tools to make precise cuts. Avoid heavy pruning, as the plant is naturally compact and dense. Light maintenance pruning can also be done to control the spread of the plant if it becomes too large for its allotted space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Havard oak","description":"Quercus havardii (common names include shinnery oak, shin oak and Havard oak) is a deciduous, low-growing, thicket-forming shrub that occupies some 2 to 3 million hectares in the southern Great Plains of North America. Clones may reach hundreds to thousands of years old, although aboveground stems typically live only 11 to 15 years. Shinnery oak stems are usually 1–2 m tall and codominate the plant community with mid- and tall-grasses which are usually taller than the oaks.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Havard oak"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Quercus havardii"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers sandy and rocky soils, and can frequently be found along roadsides.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["silverrod"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago bicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14667,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physcia adscendens, a type of lichen, thrives in environments with some humidity but generally does not require direct watering the way traditional plants do. It absorbs water and nutrients from the air, so maintaining an ambient level of moisture is beneficial. In extremely dry conditions or indoors, you can occasionally mist the lichen to simulate its natural habitat, especially during dry seasons. Avoid misting directly with tap water as the chemicals might harm it; rainwater or distilled water is preferable. Remember that overwatering or high moisture can be as harmful as dryness, so balance is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physcia adscendens requires indirect sunlight for optimal growth. It is well-suited to partially shaded positions, where it can receive filtered light. Being an outdoor organism, it typically resides in places that aren't exposed to intense, direct sunlight, as excessive light and heat can desiccate and damage it. If indoors, place it near a north-facing window or use sheer curtains to diffuse the light. Avoid placing it in direct sun for prolonged periods, especially during midday when the sun is strongest, to prevent dehydration and stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for lichens like Physcia adscendens, as they grow slowly and don’t develop in the same way as many vascular plants. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14863,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aloe vera requires infrequent watering, as it's a drought-tolerant plant primarily adapted to arid environments. Water the plant deeply but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Typically, watering every two to three weeks is sufficient during growing seasons (spring and summer). In the dormant winter months, water even less frequently. Ensure that the plant is potted in a well-draining soil mix, and use a pot with drainage holes to avoid standing water, which can cause damage to the roots and lower leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloe vera thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of light throughout the day without being subjected to direct sun, which may scorch its leaves. If outdoors, choose a partially shaded location that offers some protection from intense midday sun. If the plant starts to exhibit signs of insufficient light, such as elongated leaves or a lack of compactness, move it to a brighter spot. However, acclimate it gradually to increased light levels to avoid sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aloe vera is simple and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain a healthy appearance and prevent potential diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off the leaves at the base. You can also remove the lower leaves for aesthetic purposes or to harvest the gel. Ensure that any cuts are clean and that no leaf stubs are left, as they can rot. Avoid over-pruning, as alleys require their leaves for storing water; pruning should be minimal and only as needed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"aloe vera","description":"Aloe vera (/ˈæloʊiː/ or /ˈæloʊ/) is a plant species of the genus Aloe. After the flowering period, spent flower spikes can also be cut back to maintain the plant's appearance and redirect nutrients to healthy parts. Avoid cutting green, healthy stems or leaves as this can unnecessarily stress the plant. While Kosteletzkya pentacarpos can tolerate some partial shade, insufficient sunlight might lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If planted in a very hot or dry region, providing some light afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense sun and help maintain soil moisture levels. Planting in such a spot will ensure optimal growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kosteletzkya pentacarpos is largely a matter of removing dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. This is best done in early spring just before new growth begins. Cut back old flower stalks and foliage to tidy up the plant and potentially stimulate more robust flowering in the following season. Make clean cuts at a slight angle to promote healing. Since these plants can grow quite tall (up to 6 feet), you may also prune for shape and size control. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can also promote longer blooming periods."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Saltmarsh mallow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Saltmarsh mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Kosteletzkya pentacarpos"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Exposure to direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and negatively impact their growth. Maintain ambient temperatures and humidity that are conducive to fungal growth to ensure a healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a type of fungus, Gymnopilus sapineus does not require pruning. Instead, care involves managing the environmental conditions under which they grow. This includes removing any fruiting bodies that have matured or are starting to decay, as these can affect the overall health and cleanliness of the growing area. Thus, aim to expose it to at least 6 hours of bright, indirect sunlight daily to support optimal growth and vibrant foliage development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Proserpinaca palustris is essential to manage its shape and ensure healthy growth. Pruning should be done with sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to prevent foliage damage and potential disease spread. In aquatic environments, trimming will also encourage bushier underwater growth. Be sure to prune during the growing season for best results, and avoid excessive pruning which could stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"marsh mermaidweed","description":"Proserpinaca palustris, the marsh mermaidweed or common mermaid-weed, is a species of flowering plant in the watermilfoil family (Haloragaceae). This practice ensures the plant's vigor and flowering potential in subsequent years."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rice root","description":"Fritillaria camschatcensis is a species of flowering plant native to northeastern Asia and northwestern North America, including northern Oregon, Washington, British Columbia, Alaska, northern Japan, and the Russian Far East (Amur, Kamchatka, Khabarovsk, Magadan, Primorye, Sakhalin and the Kuril Islands). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14967,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cunninghamia lanceolata, commonly known as Chinese fir, prefers well-drained soil and should not be waterlogged. It is important to maintain evenly moist soil conditions, especially during its establishment phase. Water the plant regularly but ensure that the soil doesn't become saturated. Once established, the Chinese fir is relatively drought-tolerant but benefits from occasional deep watering during dry periods. Allow the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Adjust the frequency of watering according to the climate and weather conditions, increasing it during hotter periods and reducing during wet seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cunninghamia lanceolata thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. Full sun helps maintain a dense, healthy crown and promotes faster growth. However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hot, arid regions where some afternoon shelter may prevent leaf scorch. Ensure the planting location provides ample sunlight exposure to encourage strong development, though the tree also adapts to less-than-ideal light conditions without significant detriment, making it versatile for various landscapes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cunninghamia lanceolata is typically minimal, as the tree maintains a natural conical shape. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health and appearance. Occasionally, thinning can help improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, stimulating vigorous growth. For shaping, limit cuts to selectively removing branches to refine the tree's form without causing undue stress. Avoid heavy pruning, as this may affect growth and overall health. Always use clean, sharp tools to ensure clean cuts and reduce the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"China-fir","description":"Cunninghamia is a genus of one or two living species of evergreen coniferous trees in the cypress family Cupressaceae. They are native to China, northern Vietnam and Laos, and perhaps also Cambodia. They may reach 50 m (160 ft) in height. In vernacular use, it is most often known as Cunninghamia, but is also sometimes called \"China-fir\" (though it is not a fir). The genus name Cunninghamia honours Dr. James Cunningham, a British doctor who introduced this species...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Taiwan","Vietnam","Laos"],"other_name":["China-fir"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Cunninghamia lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
